title: [Gameplay] Recall last tick not reacting to damage
body:
When damaging a champion while his recall is almost done (during the last 0.25s) the damage won't stop the recall.

I'm aware that this likely due to the way ticks work in this game is silly.

replies.body: yep, just like your other post (flashing as last tick of morg ult etc.) this will be related to how often the game ticks.  Unfortunate side effect of having an online game where the server needs to communicate to the client!

Still don't understand how that would affect it. The way I see it in this case, the server receive a request for your champ to recall from your client and would start doing so. Then there would be the actual recall with each of its ticks, then there would be the second last tick and right after it the check for if damage has been taken, then the time between 2 ticks and finally the last tick that makes you recall. 

This would explain why the recall isn't stopped since the condition check occurs after the last tick that was executed instead of before the tick that's about to happen.
One could argue the big is that the damage hit the player when they should have based without taking damage :p. In some cases I'm sure people have died immediately upon recall.

I have never seen someone die immediately upon recall from damage they took before recalling to the base.

BUT.

I have seen people recall and immediately die to a Karthus ult (because healing in the fountain isn't instantaneous).

And, ONCE, I recalled into my base just as an Ezreal ult was passing over my fountain =\

As far as I'm aware that has been been part of the game. I have seen Rioters reference it in their explanation of gameplay and they don't seem to intend to change it.

I think your assessment is right. I remember reading that damage is applied at the end of a tick. So if damage and return occur on the same tick, then they will return and then take damage. Something like that - point being that they cannot be interrupted during the last .25 second of the return channel.
